Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing non-stationary and unbalanced growth economic models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a new method for the analysis of mathematical models of the economy. The key feature of the new method is that it will give economists new tools to build and analyze models that include not just changes over time (dynamic models) and the possibility that chance plays a role in this changes (stochastic dynamic models) but models in which the probability of a change can itself vary over time (nonstationary stochastic dynamic models). The project has clear potential to improve the methods economists currently use to answer research questions calling for these nonstationary stochastic dynamic models. In addition, the project has transformative potential; the new methods may mean that economists will be able to tackle new research problems that were impossible to answer with previous methods. If this project is fully successful, economic policymakers in the US will benefit from better scientific advice about the effects of their decisions on the US economy.

The overall goal is to develop the extended function path (EFP) method for calibrating, solving, simulating and estimating non-stationary and unbalanced growth dynamic stochastic economic models. The key feature of EFT is the notion of semi-Markov processes in which transition density functions are time dependent while also memoryless with respect to the specific history that leads to a current state. The PI team plans to apply EFP to a collection of examples that do not admit conventional stationary Markov solutions. Among these examples are two research projects. The first uses the method to analyze unbalanced growth patterns in the U.S. economy between 1963 and 2012. The second project will attempt to explain the recent economic crisis in the context of a new Keynesian model with a Taylor rule for nominal interest rates and possible non-Markov changes in government policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of real world economies is generally characterized by nonstationary and unbalanced growth patterns: the population grows; technological progress increases production capacities and augments the variety of products; relative prices change; the composition of production factors are transformed by automation and new technologies; social and political institutions evolve daily; our tastes and habits also change.   

To model such a nonstationary environment, researchers need a framework in which fundamental parameters and behavioral patterns can change over time. However, economic literature relies heavily on a notion of stationary Markov equilibrium, which does not allow for such changes. By construction, in a stationary equilibrium, all parameters of the model are assumed to be time-invariant and all growth patterns are restricted to be balanced. While the analytical and numerical tractability of Markov stationary equilibria makes them a useful and ubiquitous tool for analyzing many economic phenomena, they are not suited for analyzing those models in which behavioral patterns non-trivially change from one period to another.   

The intellectual merit of the project consists in introducing and developing extended function path (EFP ) -- a novel tractable framework for calibrating, solving, simulating and estimating non-stationary and unbalanced-growth dynamic stochastic economic models. The condition that lies in the basis of EFP is called "turnpike theorem" and can be illustrated with a simple observation: If one wants to drive to a remote destination located off the turnpike (highway), one typically tries to get on the turnpike as soon as possible, stay on the turnpike for as long as possible and get off turnpike as close as possible to the final destination. It turns out that the trajectories of dynamic economic models also obey the "turnpike" pattern.   

In the figure, we show three economies: one exists for T=15 periods, the other exists for T=25 periods and the last one is infinitely lived. If all three economies start with the same initial capital, they follow a virtually identical path for a long time and they diverge only in a close proximity to the terminal date of a finite-horizon model. Therefore, if we are interested in the behavior of an infinite-horizon non-stationary economy during some initial number of periods τ, we can accurately approximate such behavior by solving an otherwise identical finite-horizon model.   

We use EFP to analyze three applications intractable up to now. First, we extend stylized neoclassical growth models to include unbalanced growth, the entry into and exit from a monetary union, information news, anticipated policy regime switches, deterministic seasonals, and estimation of parameters in non-stationary models, among others. Second, we construct a growth model with capital-skill complementarity that can account for unbalanced growth patterns in the US economy. Finally, we solve a large-scale central banking model, namely, a version of the model used by the Bank of Canada for projection and policy analysis.   

The project has multiple broader impacts: First, the outcomes of the project were presented on 25 conferences and seminars and led to five articles that are currently under submission or revision in refereed journals. Second, the tools we developed are not limited to macroeconomics but can be applied to literally any other economic field that uses dynamic stochastic models including industrial organization, growth and development, and game theory. Third, the applications analyzed in the project are of considerable interest on their own. In particular, the analysis of the nonstationary new Keynesian model contributes to better understanding of the origins of the current and past economic crises as a sequence of unique historical events and can suggest government policies that can prevent or mitigate economic downturns in the future. In turn, the model with unbalanced growth can enhance our understanding of the sources of economic growth and can help us in designing economic policies that foster economic development. Fourth, computer codes and the data are made available to researchers including underrepresented groups, among others; our deliverables are provided in personal web pages and open source web sites such as RePEC, QuantEcon, Becker Friedman Institute of UChicago. Fifth, the project contributes to teaching and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students. In particular, 10 undergraduate and master students of Santa Clara University were hired and trained under the project. Also, the outcomes of the project were presented in graduate courses on computational economics in Indiana, Santa Clara, Stanford and Columbia Universities as well as CUNY Graduate Center. Finally, the proposed framework can be used by public and private institutions, including the US government and US Fed, for economic modeling, optimal policy choice and economics forecasts. The EFP methodology was taught in a weekly minicourse in the US Federal Reserve Board, Washington DC and a daily pre-conference workshop at Society for Computational Economics. Currently, the Bank of England is incorporating the EFP analysis in their main COMPASS model of the UK economy to assess costs of Brexit.
